key_risks: Supply chain vulnerabilities due to reliance on overseas manufacturing and geopolitical tensions
Economic sensitivity as discretionary spending on crafting products may decline during financial uncertainty
Increasing competition from rivals like Silhouette America and Brother International
Risks associated with the subscription-based pricing model for Cricut Access
controversies: Class action lawsuit settlement of $625,000 for alleged violations of California’s Unfair Competition Law, Automatic Renewal Law, Consumers Legal Remedies Act, and False Advertising Law
Significant customer backlash and subsequent reversal of decision to limit Design Space uploads for free users
social_issues: Customer dissatisfaction and reputational risk due to subscription model controversies
governance_issues: Legal risks from class action lawsuit and potential governance issues related to subscription terms transparency

sources.title: Cricut announced a new subscription model―customers shut it down
sources.snippet: The subscription model―and why it didn't work for Cricut. According to the UBS financial services firm, subscriptions are predicted to grow to $1.5 trillion by 2025, double the $650 billion it's worth now. And the move has also been successfully made by Peloton, Gillette, and GoPro, to name a few. So why didn't it work for Cricut?

sources.title: Cricut v. Enough for Everyone Inc. - Casetext
sources.snippet: Cricut alleges that "[a] key reason for amending the 2005 Agreement was that Tanner had formed [EFE] . . . to collect her patent royalties." However, in 2010, Cricut stopped making royalty payments to EFE, and in 2011, EFE sued for breach of contract and accounting. EFE prevailed on its claims and collected the full judgment with interest.
